> I want very badly for this divison and conflict to end but I don't know how to do it

There is no "how" because "how" is thought. "How" is the division, it is the idea that there is somewhere else to reach through some method.

Absence of division is the opposite of division. Therefore, there is no "doing" required, only an undoing. There is nothing for you to do other than just not engaging with thoughts about division. Being undivided is the natural state. There are only thoughts about being divided, but you are never in them, and so they eventually vanish.

> I want to fix this misunderstanding, that I carry with me, about myself

Misunderstanding is the thought that you can carry misunderstanding. Unicorns couldn't misunderstand anything, since they are imagined or thought of. Same goes for you. 

Absence of misunderstanding is understanding, so there is only an "undoing" required, not any "how" or "doing."  

Trying to understand unicorns is just more misunderstanding, because it is in thought. There is nothing to understand because there is nothing in thought, and there is no such sense perception as "misunderstanding" outside of thought.

> I hope to stumble upon some thought that could cause a click

Thoughts couldn't cause a click, or anything for that matter. Thoughts about causes aren't actually causes, they're just thoughts. Try to find a cause for your experience, without thinking. Which sense perception is a cause going to be made of?

Thoughts communicate but dont really describe anything outside of itself. I think this is very important to get.

Thoughts point at things like a finger does. But actually the finger and the thing being pointed at are the same occurrence. There aren't "things" until thought points to it, and so things are literally thought. The finger is never what it points to. Same goes for thought. So notice that the thing that the thought points to vanishes once the thought is gone. 

Thoughts seem to "hone in" or "cut out" certain parts of experience. But a thought couldn't ever actually do this, because it is just a thought. Whatever the thought points to disappears with the thought because it is the thought. 

You say you're looking at a table, but that is just the thought pointing. Your experience has more things than a table. And so you couldn't experience "table", just the thought of it.

"believing content" is thinking you are affected by the thought, it is assumptions about thought. Assumptions are thoughts about thoughts. "I feel this way because of yesterday" (even though thought and feeling could not be caused by yesterday, the contents and claims of the thought are believed as a genuine cause)

More accurate is that you are viewing the thought, you aren't being in the thought. You can't be inside what you are viewing. You can't read a story while being in a story. You are aware of the thought and how it feels currently, although the thought claims something not current (yesterday, tomorrow, unicorns, etc.)
All your reasonings for why you are or aren't SR don't apply to anything or anyone aside from what exists in mind. Just let that thought disappear as well.

Every single distinction your mind makes, is mind. Every word and letter. That's why it goes away when you stop thinking. There are no descriptions and distinctions until you think of them; thinking is distinction. Experience has no sense to distinguish another sense. It can only imagine.

> but what is it that experiences an event or thought?

Any answer to this would be thought, or a division/separation of the event experienced. The question assumes that the event or experience is divided by something.

Consider that in order for something to experience an event or thought, that being or entity would only exist in relation to said event or thought. You can't be someone who thinks, without the thought which is thought of. You can't be someone who steps in dung, without dung. Almost like there is no separation between the event and the perceiver of the event.

I think my mind was very much like that too.

Use the analytical power to examine what is beyond your mind:
"What happens when I'm not thinking?" "What is thinking?" etc. 

Dive straight into what thoughts and mind are made out of, not what they claim to be made out of. I can think of unicorns but that doesn't mean my mind is a unicorn.

Don't examine contents of mind, unless you want to learn about unicorns. Examine how you relate to mind in the present experience.

Whatever conclusion you reach, if it is wrong, it will often naturally become disillusioned. There will be slight confusion/angst/uncertainty about it, and those emotions will certainly be felt, which always creates the opportunity to examine and dispel them. Emotions and feelings are guidance. Pay attention to feeling as it happens currently, because feeling is always current, whereas mind points to things which are not current. Mind often obscures or hides feeling by creating cause/reason for feeling, like "this feeling is caused by yesterday or tomorrow."

> where does my personality come from?

Wherever it comes from would be ***thoughts about*** personality.

Like asking "where does the taste of vanilla come from?"

> My understanding is that I am an entity that has the ability to think which mistakes myself for being in thought.

This itself is thought. You can't understand unicorns.

You are not an entity which mistakes itself in thought, you are aware of the thought that you are an entity which believes it is in thought.

Unicorns couldn't believe they are in thoughts. That itself is a belief/thought.

What is experienced are assumptions about thoughts, and how those assumptions feel in the present moment. There is no "being inside of thought", that only exists for an imaginary entity, like unicorns. There is only the awareness of a thought, and then the further thoughts/assumptions about it which you become aware of. Like getting lost in reading a book, you don't ever become part of the story just by reading it, you are only ever reading it. You are only ever being aware of thoughts, not being in thoughts.

> However, there's still duality there, right?

Right.

> The idea that there is still an entity that exists and is the controller which is separate than everything else.

Personality could not be separated or imagined, because it is like perceiving colors or sound or taste. It is a factual spontaneous experience, as is all experience.

There is really no such thing as "my personality" aside from the thought, that is a thought which I have to verbalize for communication purposes. Meaning, personality is not "yours" (how could someone be separate from a personality?), and it is not separate from experience. Whatever is imagined is just imagined and experienced as imagination, period. 

If "my personality" is taken as a genuine occurrence, that means you believe your experience is split in two, which could not be the case. We have to be careful, because the thought "my personality" is not what personality is.

> do you have any thoughts on that?

That seems pretty idiosyncratic and I don't know if I would be confident ascribing stages to every person like that or telling them to expect it. It always feels that way when people try to put things in stages. And the stages are simply just maps, they couldn't ever reflect what is true anyways. Why point to maps when you can point to what is true? Stages are just extra ideas. If you want a good summary of stages (prior to SR and somewhat after), Ox Herding Pictures are best IMO.

"Self-realization" is not a precursor to anything so there is no second, third, etc. It's like realizing you forgot your keys or something. There are no stages to something like that, because stages are duality. Can it affect how you want to live your life or something? Sure. That's just life though, not self-realization. Any stages only make sense to me if they come before SR, otherwise what is being described is really not directly related to SR.

> I imagine myself suffering for not having the thing and emphasising with that suffering figure.

Can you imagine suffering?

> In the case with the bear or a unicorn it is indeed like that and o dont have problems with those thoughts. Cause I see that Im already not affected by that imaginary thing. 

Right.

> But in my example with a woman I first need to have her and then loose.

> Or with occupation it means that I dont have it right now and it feels bad.

If you don't have it right now, it could not cause anything right now.

What doesn't cause anything, could not feel bad. What doesn't exist, could not feel bad. Only the idea of it, could.

What exists, is the idea/assumption.

Idea/assumptions don't exist, aside from ideas/assumptions. You couldn't be an assumption, after all.

It's how the idea/assumption feels, currently, to you. 

Look at what the idea/assumption appears as, and ask yourself if you are in it.

> So me not having it right now is basically failing without trying and it feels awful.

In a sense, it is experientially the same for me. I don't have any of those things right now (occupation, women, etc). Knowing this, it would seem that the content of thought seems to be irrelevant/illusory to what causes the actual feeling.

"I feel this way because of what is not happening right now" is an intellectual illusion which points to non-existence. Non-existence, or what is not happening now, could not be the cause or explanation for what is experienced now, by you.

It's the ideas/assumptions/meanings created right now. What is not with you right now could not cause those ideas/assumptions/meanings. 

Meaning, it couldn't be something in the future causing the feeling/ideas occurring right now. 

Look watchfully at what is occurring and causing things ***right now.***

> This is my life basically, just constantly distracting myself with other things.

The idea that your life is "distracting yourself with things" feels like that idea, but couldn't actually be what is in that idea, because life is aware of the idea.

Instead of trying to explain or create an effort in rationalizing the source of feeling, try to look for the source of feeling in direct experience. Give priority to what feeling is saying about what you are currently experiencing.

> Apathy seems to stem from loss of motivation, from fear of failure.

Apathy is a thought about failure, and how it feels.

> But yeah, I think I thought that its gonna fail anyway and that was the end of it.

That would definitely create apathy. 

"Being in" this thought is apathy. 

Being in this thought is identity.

> Tho in case of a woman I look at one and feel bad right there and now. Tho I guess its the same thought. So yeah, unwanted things that havent occurred yet feel as apathy. 

That's a great observation. Be watchful of how thoughts feel, and how they feel when they aren't there.

Feeling is much more truthful than the content of thought, because feeling happens currently, whereas thought only happens in thought. 

Example:

"I'm experiencing something that hasn't occurred and it feels bad"

But wait, how could something not occurring, feel bad, currently?

Where is the feeling coming from currently? Something current couldn't be "not occurring"? What is the feeling telling me about the thought?

Is it possible to want something that you already have? If not, how is it possible to imagine something you don't want? Wouldn't that mean you can be inside of imagination?

You couldn't really **truly** imagine what you don't want, because that would mean you are experiencing what you don't want. You can't really imagine that you don't want a bear in your living room, because you can't imagine bears. There is just the thought or appearance of what ***would*** be unwanted, if you could be inside of imagination. But awareness could not be aware of "woulds", because you are not imaginary. It could only appear as that, in thought, which you are aware of.

In other words, if what you don't want is being imagined, then what you want is already fulfilled, because you could not be inside of imagination. The fact that you can imagine it is proof that you already have what you want. It's like saying "I don't want to be a unicorn."

On the other hand, what is wanted always happens currently, and it is created currently, and it feels good currently. It doesn't need "you" to be inside of imagination. It is quite literally being and experiencing what you want, and thus simultaneously creating what you want. What you want feels aligned with what you are, what you don't want feels like being what you aren't.

Very simply, if you are experiencing something, it is not a cause. Cause is explanation or relation.

If you believe you are inside of the cause/reasoning/thought which appears, it could seem like you are in a world which is caused by things.

Cause is a relationship between two things, like cause and effect. If A does not exist then B could not. It is a relationship between two things, first and foremost, inferred through mind. A division.

Cause is reasoning which comes after the fact of experience. You flip on a light switch, light appears, mind reasons afterwards: the light is caused by flipping the switch. But this reasoning doesn't really speak to experience, because there is nothing other than your own experience which could cause an experience. Light is not the experience of a switch being flipped. A switch being flipped is not the experience of light. Mind "glues" the two experiences together and creates a cause. The cause is an explanation for what you are currently experiencing, it is not what occurs but an explanation for what occurs. If I wiped your memory, you would forget what caused the light to occur because it is not actually in experience, only the end result (light) is. Cause is never experienced outside of itself, cause is always an explanation for what is experienced. It is logic, division, mind, intellect.

Experience could not be aware of something that causes experience, because it would have to be experienced.

It is like playing Minecraft and saying "this game is caused by code." Code is not experienced during the game because that is not what the game is. Only the idea of code could be experienced during the game, which is just an idea, and not code.

Whether you blame yourself or someone else, it is felt the same way, because you are the one blaming. You are experiencing that idea. In regards to someone else, there is also a subsequent anger because they are seen as causing the feeling of blame which needs to be alleviated.

There's definitely a difference between being a human and thinking that you're a human. What is left over aside from thinking is what you are being, and what you are being is not thinking. You are also being the thinking, therefore never in the thinking. You can't read a story while being in a story. 

Notice how when waking up or drifting into sleep, there is literally no perception of the world and how you relate to it. There might be dreaming, which you could say is a "different world." Or perhaps there is nothing at all. A brief blankness. Then perhaps you get your first whiff of coffee in the morning and start thinking "oh yeah im a human being, I went to sleep yesterday, now its time for me to have some coffee in the kitchen" and so the mind is being the thought of the world again. 

Notice how you can remember things which relate you to the world, but there is a period where you **don't** remember. If you are in the world, why must you remember something you are inside of?

"I am a human" (if believed) is being in the story. You are being the thought "I am a human." You are being those words, not being in them. You can't be inside of what you are, that is division/separation/imagination.

But once you stop imagining, it's not even "a human" left over, that's still being imagined and spoken for the sake of communication. It's you being aware of the experience, and what is aware of experience can't be in the experience. Whatever you are aware of can't be you, because you are aware of it.

"Me as a human" is itself the imagination you are being, not being inside of. 

If you truly perceive yourself as a human, or anything for that matter, who is perceiving that? If you read a book about wizards and dragons, who is perceiving wizards and dragons? Notice the nature of the perceiver is to "hide behind." The nature of being aware is being ***aware of***, not being inside of what you are aware of.

I believe that truly realizing that the emotion is how the thought feels ***currently*** is equivalent to SR, because it "disconnects" you from the reasoning inside of the intellect.

When I say "emotion is how the thought feels currently", completely grasping that is what I believe would create SR. When you grasp that then you "move out of" thought. Because all that happens is what is being felt currently.

What I'm saying right now doesn't "become untrue" after SR, because all I am saying is that emotions are felt currently, and it is true that things are always felt currently. Emotions are true. Thought rationalizes emotions and tries to turn the emotion into a thought like "my emotion comes from yesterday, tomorrow, this, that, etc."

If I'm not experiencing something it doesn't mean you're not experiencing something. I am communicating based on what you are asking about your experience. It's more like I'm describing the weather yesterday. I'm not saying it is occurring to me, I'm just saying how it occurs and that the same weather might be occurring to you right now.

To put it succinctly, I'm describing how emotions and thoughts are misperceived prior to SR. That mechanism doesn't "vanish" or "become untrue" after SR, but the mechanism is acting maladaptively because you believe you are in the thought.

You weren't ever actually inside of your thoughts prior to SR, so you never actually contradict SR. You simply think it. Thinking is not the same as existing or being as that thing. It is not untrue that your thoughts feel bad currently. It is untrue that you are in the thought. When you stop "being in the thought", you stop feeling bad currently, so they are linked in that way.

The emotion is not caused by anything because nothing is causing the thought, and emotion/thought are simultaneous. They share the same fate of having no cause because the emotion is the thought.

There is no doer/thinker/causer in experience which can do/think/cause the emotion.

There is nothing "underneath" the thought to support it, it is not supported by anything which isn't just more thought. 

The emotion is "embedded" in the thought without any cause or logic which goes beyond the thought itself.

The mind "runs off" with the logic of the thought and mistakes it for a cause.

"I did this yesterday" occurs presently as a thought, it feels bad, the bad feeling is attributed to "doing things yesterday", not "thinking about yesterday right now."

Thinking about yesterday right now is not caused by yesterday, and nothing right now is causing what is happening right now.

> The emotion is caused by belief about thought, not thought itself

The idea that emotion is caused by belief is the same as the idea that emotions are caused by thoughts, because beliefs are thoughts. It is still in the paradigm of reasons.

The feeling of the thought is perceived like this: "I feel this way because I am inside of the thought, the feeling is proof, otherwise why would I feel bad?"

But it's actually how the thought feels, not the content of thought. You aren't in the content of the thought. You're being aware of how the thought feels presently. 

The reason and feeling occur simultaneously. The mind justifies this by saying "the reason is the cause for the feeling", but all causes are simply just thoughts, not causes. You can't be in the thought therefore you can't be affected by the cause and thus the cause can't cause the emotion.

Nothing is causing the thought. 

Anything causing the thought is another thought. 

The emotion is not caused by the reason inside of the thought. 

Nothing in experience is being caused. Experience only knows experience, not what causes experience.

Experience is aware of reasons and causes, as thoughts. 

Reasons and causes are thoughts, not reasons and causes. 

Experience can't be aware of something that causes experience to be aware of something.

Experience is aware of the thought "this is caused by this."

Experience is simultaneously aware of how that thought feels.

Both the feeling and the reason are uncaused. Thought can't cause anything outside of thought. Reason can't cause anything outside of reason. Reason is intellect/mind/imagination. Imagination can't cause anything because unicorns can't cause anything.

Believing in the reason causes it to perpetuate, making a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you believe 1+1=2 is true, you will imagine it every time someone asks "what is 1+1?" If you believe that your reason is true, you will imagine it every time someone asks about it. And if you believe in it, you will act like you believe in it.

Whatever reason you come up with, you cannot be inside of or affected by, because you are being aware of the reason. Like reading a book. You can't be affected by what is in the book because you are the one viewing it.

There is no reason or cause for how the thought feels.

The feeling is true. The feeling is then justified or rationalized, but this justification obscures what is causing the feeling.

Example:

"I feel this way because of what happened yesterday", even though you don't experience yesterday.

Ultimately, there is no reason. 

Or, you could say that the paradigm of reasons is the reason, but maybe that phrasing is too convoluted and paradoxical.

It's the idea that there is a reason which perpetuates "it."

"i feel this way because of this reason, etc."

"It" occurs because you are free to imagine whatever reason you want. If you feel bad about something, you can find someone to blame, which feels bad. If you can't find someone to blame, you blame yourself, which feels bad. If you don't blame yourself, you blame the universe, which feels bad. etc.

You can't desire the future while imagining yourself inside the future, otherwise the desire is fulfilled:

https://discord.com/channels/1129343306485215342/1129343306485215345/1223301197906186355

In other words, desiring what you want always happens currently, as your current self. 

It is imagining yourself as something undesired which "places you in time" and creates the desire to be your current self again.

Perceiving yourself inside of what is undesired splits you in two and places you outside of present experience into either past or future. For example, regret caused by thinking about how the injury happened is the desire to be your current self outside of that past scenario.

Past and future is equivalent to worry.

Worrying about the past and future is the same as believing in past and future. It's the same idea/thought/belief.

Only what is in past and future can worry about past and future.

Why worry about thinking presently?

The thought "it's just a thought" is also just a thought, which is why the emotion is not resolved. 

Emotion is the thought. It's not the reason in the thought. Thoughts can think of reasons, but those reasons don't cause emotions. 

You can only **think **of what causes emotions, but emotions themselves are always **felt**, never thought of.  In the same way how the color red is always seen, not thought of. 

The content of thought is not causing emotion, emotion is how interacting with the thought feels in the present moment. 

Emotion doesn't happen because you did something you regret yesterday, emotion is how thinking about that feels currently. Emotion is not how yesterday feels, it's how the thought about yesterday feels **now.**

> The word I was always pointing at the experience not the body even though grammatically there appears to be separation.

Yes exactly.

Grammatical separation happens purely for the sake of communication with others. Communicating to yourself in your head "I am this, that, etc." is redundant because you are already being the thing you are communicating.

> it seems like your saying to just let it go but I can't seem to

Thought can't let go of thought. 

The idea of "7 years" and the idea of "letting go" are still both the same idea. The idea that you have something to let go of is the same as the idea that you haven't let go. It's the same occurrence.

There can only be one thought at a time, either you are worrying about letting go of thoughts, or you are worrying about what you did 7 years ago. Both are worrying about the same idea. Both are the same idea.

Letting go is the idea that there is something to let go of.

There is nothing in the thought to let go of.

You are being the thought, you are not being something which has to let go of something in the thought.

"Letting go of what I did" is the same as thinking that you are in a thought about something you did.

> there's nothing I can do about it

Nothing is all that needs to be done.

There is the thought that there is something to do about another thought.

There is the thought that something happened 7 years ago.

You are being the thought. You are not being in the thought. 

Check direct experience to verify that you are perceiving thought, and thus you can't be inside of the thought you are perceiving.

To get an idea of how different thoughts can feel, or if you need help letting go of the stove, you can go for a walk outside. Or you can listen to music. Or you can go to a cafe and order something. Pay attention to the thoughts these activities create (or uncreate), and how that feels in contrast, and how it feels to be that instead of what you were being previously. Creating and being what you want feels good because you are being what you want, whereas thinking of what you dont want feels like being what you don't want.

What an emotion appears as is often obscured by justifications and causes for the emotion, like I feel regret because I did this, and because I will now experience this tomorrow, etc. instead of seeing clearly and presently that the emotion is the very thought that is occurring right now, and it will vanish as the thought itself vanishes. Emotion and thought is not caused by something 7 years ago, it occurs right now without a cause other than what is occurring right now. The emotion is not caused by any reason other than the thought occurring right now, and any reason explaining how the thought feels would simply be another thought.

The pain from a hot stove occurs because you are touching it right now, not because someone decided to build the stove 7 years ago. If you rationalize the cause of the emotion as something which occurred 7 years ago, the emotion stays perpetual because you cannot travel back in time 7 years. If the pain from the stove is caused by something 7 years ago, then you cannot travel back 7 years to stop it from being built, and so you continue to keep your hand on the stove, unless you realize that the entire thing is one occurrence in the present moment. If you look at the emotion as something occurring now and not as a reason which is not occurring now, then you can finally truly observe the thought which is causing the emotion as one singular occurrence.

Loneliness is further felt and perceived by being the thought of not having friends and the subsequent future that causes you to imagine. Loneliness is how the idea of being a separate self interacting with other separate selves feels. Loneliness is how the idea of having a past that you can hide feels. The desire created by those thoughts of loneliness is the desire to recuperate the love which is lost by not having friends, which is what the emotion of loneliness (lack of love in relationship) is.

Regret is how the thought everything Ive done in the last seven years feels. Emotion is the thought.

Self-referencing (thoughts about self) can feel very emotionally powerful; like disgust or regret. Emotional guidance is felt accordingly in regards to thoughts about things that arent you but are believed to be you. 

Regret is not caused by 7 years of actions because thoughts are not caused by 7 years of actions. Thought occurs now without any action. The "cause" of thought, is just more thought, and thus not actually a cause at all, just a thought about cause. Inspect direct experience to verify. 

Regret is being the thought that there are 7 years of actions. But what is being thought cannot be in thought. 

You are being the thought, you are not being in the thought. You are not being 7 years right now, you are being the thought of 7 years, right now. 

Regret is the desire to change what you did in the past. But that splits you into two (past and future). There cant be you in the past which regrets being there, there is you being a thought about the past.

Emotions guide you away from being in the thought. Like how pain guides you away from touching a hot stove. The guidance of emotions is often obscured by reasonings like "I'm feeling this because of what happened 7 years ago" which is actually how the thought feels right now, it is not how 7 years feels like.

Emotions are desires created by the thought which can be further inspected and dispelled. In this case, regret is a desire to change what you did in the past, which is the same as the thought "I am in the past." The desire is ultimately to just be with yourself, currently.

Thought creates an "extra self" by claiming that you are in the thought, as in "I did this 7 years ago." But whatever claims or perceives that cannot be in the claim or perception. Inspect direct experience to verify.

You are always only ever being "senses." 

Intellect on intellect is believing that you are experiencing whatever the thought proposes, but the thought is also perceived through senses the same way any other perception is.

"Senses" can appear as a thought that you are inside of your intellect. Thought is a sense which can turn into a statement about "me being inside of thought."

Examples of thoughts appearing as you inside of it: "I have work tomorrow, I did this yesterday, I am experiencing myself inside of a world made of atoms, etc."

Intellect/thought is made of separations and self-referential statements, like "I, me, this, that, etc"  which "places you" inside of the thought.

Senses can appear as thought but can't be inside of thought. The thing viewing thought cannot be in thought. There can only be a thought "I am inside of this thought", which senses appear as.

Senses cannot say "my experience of the color red is made out of receptors and atoms bouncing here and there", sense can only sense red. Sense can appear as a thought saying "red is made out of receptors and atoms bouncing here and there", which would be sense sensing thought, not red.

In the same way how a story is always viewed through a book, but the story is not about a book. It is about a world which has wizards, people, magic, dragons, etc. But that is merely how the book appears as. The book is not how wizards, people, magic, dragons, etc. appear as, because a book cannot be those things, it can only be a book.

When you read a book, you aren't experiencing the world in the book, you're thinking about it. When you think, you aren't experiencing what you're thinking about, you're thinking about it.

Thinking is not intellect on intellect. Thinking is you thinking. Intellect on intellect is you thinking that you are in thinking.

"Distracting" is being disengaged from self-referential thought so that you cant be with the thought anymore. In other words, anything that takes up space in the thinking faculty for something that has nothing to do with self-image. There is no examining self-image when running from a bear, for example. Or you could be disengaged from thought by another thought caused by someone else or something around you (you're at the line at starbucks and someone asks you what you want to order which forces you to think about what you want to order). You essentially wanna be in a space where you're free to think what you want.

It is as simple as reading a story, getting lost in the story, and then realizing that you are not experiencing the story aside from your thoughts about it.

All that needs to be noticed is that the emotion is caused by the thought itself, not contents of thought. The content holds zero weight. Meaning, you aren't in the content of thought, you are experiencing how the thought feels to look at. 

You cant be stressed about work tomorrow, stress is how the thought "i have work tomorrow" feels. The emotion comes prior to tomorrow therefore it cant be caused by tomorrow therefore you don't feel tomorrow, you feel emotion and thought currently. It's like touching a hot stove and going "my hand burns because i have to use the stove tomorrow." The logic and reasoning veils and obscures the guidance created by emotions and feeling. Pain guides you away from the stove. Anxiety guides you away from the thought.

The emotions are real and they make it feel real. But that is just how the thought feels, currently. Explaining or rationalizing the emotion obscures what is presently occurring, for example "i feel anxiety because I have work tomorrow" blames "tomorrow" as the cause of the emotion, even though tomorrow has not occurred yet. The thought and emotion is not caused by work tomorrow because it comes prior to tomorrow. It is purely the interaction you're having with the thought. 

It is as simple as seeing "tomorrow is not happening right now, thought and emotion is, therefore I cant be worried about tomorrow, I can only experience how the idea of tomorrow feels." It is as simple as checking direct experience and seeing that the contents of your thought don't exist once you stop thinking them. There is no tomorrow when you stop thinking about it. There is no story from a book when you stop thinking about it. There is no emotional reaction to tomorrow when you stop thinking about it. There is no emotional reaction to a book when you stop thinking about it.
Noticing self-referential thoughts is all that needs to be done.
There is nothing you can do wrong, there is just the thought that "you are doing something wrong", which can be felt and examined and reduced to thought.

>  I feel like idk wtf Im doing.

The thought "i dont know wtf im doing" feels a certain way. 

That is how the thought feels. Like how a hot stove feels. 

The feeling doesn't exist without the thought and vice versa. 

You can't know that you don't know without the thought that you don't know.

You can't be burned by a stove without a stove. 

> Like, I have no idea what direction to go in anymore.

Look at how thoughts feel, and why the thought feels. 

Notice the intrinsic separation in all thoughts which try to describe you. "I, they, them, this, tomorrow, yesterday, etc."

Notice the contrast between thoughts of separation, and your awareness of the thought and experience as a whole.

For example, a thought about tomorrow can't be caused by tomorrow because it happens prior to tomorrow. Thus there is no tomorrow in your experience of yourself, there is just the thought of it, which you cannot ever be inside of, since you are not experiencing tomorrow. There is a dissonance here between awareness and the thoughts which try to describe awareness.

> Could that be the I?

"I" is always being a thought. 

Like "I like this."

Prior to thought comes the thing itself; the actual awareness of it. 

If you like water, you feel it through thirst or ideation. You don't have to think it, because you are it.

You don't have to think to yourself "I am thirsty" to know you are thirsty, because you literally **are thirsty**. You can feel it. You are being it already, without thinking that you are being it. The thinking of it creates two; it creates separation.

Every single word in the sentence "I am thirsty" points to the exact same singular occurrence of "thirst." There is no separation. There is no perceiver of thirst, doer of thirst, controller of thirst, etc. Those are more thoughts perceived as thoughts. There is just thirst. There is just what you are, there is no controller/perceiver/doer of what you are.
